headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General Issues Consumer Alert About Apple Airtags' Tracking Threat
sentences: "It's uncomfortable knowing that people have these devices they can just pop into your bag, especially because I am from (New) Jersey, so I'm really far from home," Pitt student Renita Mehta said Wednesday.
Also, watch for the "item detected near you" alert on your iPhone, and you can download the Tracker Detect app if you are an Android user to check for Bluetooth trackers within range.

PITTSBURGH (KDKA) -- Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro has issued a consumer alert about the malicious use of Apple AirTags.
Just this week, state police said a man from Apollo violated a PFA when he used the device to keep tabs on his ex-girlfriend.
There have been reports of people having had their locations tracked unknowingly without their consent by AirTags.
He also said Apple users should update their devices regularly to have the most up-to-date security features.
Shapiro's consumer alert came with some advice about how to be aware that an AirTag is tracking you.
According to Shapiro, people are finding Airtags stashed in their cars, purses and coat pockets.
The alert was issued Wednesday, with Shapiro saying he wants everyone to be aware.
In the wrong hands, Shapiro said the Bluetooth device can "lead to disaster."
Shapiro reinforced that not all AirTags are being used for the wrong reasons.
"But it's good to know there's awareness of these things."
Mehta said she is happy that this is being addressed.
He is now facing several charges.
